courseTitle: Information Literacy and Research for Modeling and Simulation Engineers
courseDescription: An introduction to methods and standards for locating and using information in the discipline of modeling and simulation engineering.  Topics include:  assessing information requirements; searching for, locating and evaluating information sources related to modeling and simulation; tools for managing, sharing, and presenting information; and ethical issues in the use of information.  Students will complete exercises and research on topics involving information of interest to modeling and simulation engineers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of modeling and simulation engineering principles
Effective use of tools for managing, sharing, and presenting information
Locating and assessing information sources relevant to modeling and simulation
Ethical use of information in the field of engineering
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Sharing information in a professional context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Research on topics involving information of interest to modeling and simulation engineers
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing information for use in modeling and simulation
Leading research efforts in modeling and simulation engineering

courseTitle: Introduction to Modeling and Simulation Engineering
courseDescription: This is the first course for Modeling and Simulation Engineering (M&SE) students.  M&SE discipline is surveyed at an overview level of detail.  Topics include basic definitions, M&S paradigms and methodologies, applications, design processes, and human factors.  Information literacy and research methods are addressed.  Papers and oral presentations are required and allow the student to investigate different aspects of the discipline.  The course provides a general conceptual framework for further M&SE studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Employing information literacy and research methods
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Investigating different aspects of M&S discipline

courseDescription: An introduction to the modeling and simulation of discrete-state, event-driven systems.  Topics include: basic properties and terminology for discrete event systems (DES); models for DES including queuing models, Petri nets, and state automata; and methodologies for simulating DES models.  Investigation of the steps of a DES simulation study including problem formulation, conceptual model design, simulation model development, input data modeling, output data analysis, verification and validation, and design of simulation experiments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Modeling and simulating discrete-state, event-driven systems
Understanding properties and terminology of discrete event systems
Working with models for DES including queuing models, Petri nets, and state automata
Applying methodologies for simulating DES models
Verification and validation of DES models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing output data from DES models

courseDescription: A laboratory course designed to provide a hands-on introduction to the development and application of discrete event simulation.  Topics include an introduction to one or more discrete event simulation tools, common modeling constructs, data gathering and input data modeling, design of simulation experiments, output data analysis, and verification and validation.  The design and implementation of a series of increasingly complex simulations of various discrete event systems are conducted.  The laboratory is designed to accompany MSIMÂ 205.  Student written reports are required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development and application of discrete event simulation
Operation of discrete event simulation tools
Verification and validation of simulation results
Design and implementation of complex simulations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving through design and implementation of simulation experiments
Analytical skills through output data analysis
Verification and validation of simulation results
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing a series of increasingly complex simulations

courseDescription: An introduction to the fundamentals of modeling and simulating continuous-state, time-driven systems. Topics include differential equation representation of systems, formulation of state variable equations, and numerical integration techniques including Taylor series, families of Runge-Kutta and Adams methods.  Application domains considered include physical, biological, electrical systems, and real-time simulations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying numerical integration techniques to real-world problems

courseDescription: Introduction to data structures, algorithms, programming methodologies, and software architectures in support of computer simulation.  Topics include lists, queues, sets, trees, searching, sorting, reusable code, and order of complexity.  Simulation structures developed include event lists, time management, and queuing models.  Software models are implemented and tested.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to work with lists, queues, sets, trees
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and solving problems related to data structures and algorithms
Ability to design efficient algorithms based on time and space complexity
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing various data structures

courseDescription: Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and Career Development Services prior to the semester in which the work is to take place.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of specific job roles and requirements
Familiarity with industry-standard tools and practices
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with superiors and peers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to apply academic knowledge to real-world problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adapting to corporate structure and culture

courseDescription: Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students to gain short duration career-related experience.
Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students to gain short duration career-related experience.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of chosen field's technical requirements

courseDescription: A laboratory course designed to provide a hands-on introduction to the development and application of continuous simulation.  Topics include an introduction to one or more continuous simulation tools, modeling of various physics-based systems, and numerical solution of differential equations.  The design and implementation of a series of increasingly complex simulations of various continuous systems are conducted.  The laboratory is designed to accompany MSIMÂ 320.  Student written reports are required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design and implementation of complex simulations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for simulation design and implementation

courseDescription: A laboratory course designed to provide a hands-on introduction to the development of simulation software.  Topics include data structures, algorithms, and simulation executives.  The students will conclude with the development of a basic simulation executive capable of managing discrete event simulations.  The laboratory is designed to accompany MSIMÂ 331.  Student written reports are required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development of a basic simulation executive
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Practical application of algorithms in software development

courseTitle: Topics in Modeling and Simulation Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on the recent developments in modeling and simulation engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of recent developments in modeling and simulation engineering
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Keeping up-to-date with recent developments in the field

courseDescription: An introduction to distributed simulation.  Topics include motivation for using distributed simulation, distributed simulation architectures, time management issues, and distributed simulation approaches.  Current standards for distributed simulation are presented.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of current standards for distributed simulation
Handling time management issues in distributed simulation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining the motivation for using distributed simulation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the efficiency and effectiveness of different distributed simulation approaches
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and managing distributed simulation projects
Leading a team in a distributed simulation environment

courseDescription: An introductory course focused on game development theory and modern practices with emphasis on educational game development.  Topics include game architecture, computer graphics theory, user interaction, audio, high level shading language, animation, physics, and artificial intelligence.  The developed games can run on a variety of computer, mobile, and gaming platforms.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Version control for game assets and code

courseDescription: The goal of this course is to develop understanding of the various modeling paradigms appropriate for capturing system behavior and conducting digital computer simulation of many types of systems. The techniques and concepts discussed typically include UML, concept graphs, Bayesian nets, Markov models, Petri nets, system dynamics, Bond graphs, etc. Students will report on a particular technique and team to implement a chosen system model.  (cross-listed with ECEÂ 410)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Team collaboration for system model implementation
Presenting reports on a particular technique
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying appropriate system behavior capturing methods
Analyzing system behavior through digital computer simulation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating team for system model implementation

courseDescription: This course focuses on cybersecurity theory, information protection and assurance, and computer systems and networks security. The objectives are to understand the basic security models and concepts, learn fundamental knowledge and tools for building, analyzing, and attacking modern security systems, and gain hands-on experience in cryptographic algorithms, security fundamental principles, and Internet security protocol and standards.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of security models and concepts
Use of tools for building, analyzing, and attacking modern security systems
Understanding of Internet security protocol and standards
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in the context of security systems attacks
Analytical skills for understanding and applying cryptographic algorithms
Ability to interpret and apply Internet security protocol and standards

courseDescription: Cyber Physical Systems (CPS) integrate computing, networking, and physical processes. The objectives of this course are to learn the basic concepts, technologies and applications of CPS, understand the fundamental CPS security challenges and national security impact, and gain hands-on experience in CPS infrastructures, critical vulnerabilities, and practical countermeasures. Cross-listed with ECEÂ 419/CYSEÂ 419.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Cyber Physical Systems (CPS) concepts
Knowledge of CPS technologies and applications
Understanding the national security impact of CPS
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex CPS concepts and issues
Collaborating on identifying and addressing CPS vulnerabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing countermeasures for CPS security challenges
Understanding and addressing the national security implications of CPS
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading initiatives to address CPS security challenges
Organizing and managing CPS infrastructure security

courseDescription: The course provides a practical treatment of computer graphics and visualization with emphasis on modeling and simulation applications. It covers digital image and signal processing basics such as sampling and discrete Fourier transform, computer graphics fundamentals, visualization principles, and software architecture for visualization in modeling and simulation. Written communication and information literacy skills are stressed in this course. (Cross listed with ECEÂ 406/506.) (Offered fall)
Technical and Digital Skills: Software architecture for visualization in modeling and simulation

courseDescription: An introduction to analysis techniques appropriate to the conduct of modeling and simulation studies.  Topics include input modeling, random number generation, output analysis, variance reduction techniques, and experimental design.  In addition, techniques for verification & validation are introduced.  Course concepts are applied to real systems and data.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying course concepts to real systems and data

courseDescription: Introduction to basic concepts in medical image analysis.  Medical image registration, segmentation, feature extraction, and classification are discussed.  Basic psychophysics, fundamental ROC analysis and FROC methodologies are covered.  Cross-listed with ECEÂ 462/ECEÂ 562.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementation of ROC and FROC analysis methodologies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving through image registration and segmentation

courseTitle: Design and Modeling of Autonomous Robotic Systems
courseDescription: This course focuses on autonomous robotics systems with emphasis on using modeling and simulation (M&S) for system level design and testing. Fundamental concepts associated with autonomous robotic systems are discussed. Course topics include: robotic control, architectures, and sensors as well as more advanced concepts such as error propagation, localization, mapping and autonomy. Design strategies that leverage M&S to accelerate the development and testing of sophisticated autonomous robotic algorithms for individual or teams of robots are covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design strategies leveraging modeling and simulation
Development and testing of autonomous robotic algorithms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Designing strategies for modeling and simulation
Developing and testing autonomous robotic algorithms
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and accelerating the development of autonomous robotic systems

courseDescription: Course provides an overview of theory, tools and practice of cyber security and information assurance through prevention, detection and modeling of cyber attacks and recovery from such attacks. Techniques for security modeling, attack modeling, risk analysis and cost-benefit analysis are described to manage the security of cyber systems. Fundamental principles of cyber security and their applications for protecting software and information assets of individual computers and large networked systems are explored. Anatomy of some sample attacks designed to compromise confidentiality, integrity and availability of cyber systems are discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Protection of software and information assets
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of fundamental principles of cyber security

courseDescription: This course presents the basic techniques for transportation data analytics. It will discuss statistical modeling, prominent algorithms, and visualization approaches to analyze both small- and large-scale data sets generated from transportation systems. Practices of using different data for various real-world traffic/transportation applications and decision making will also be discussed., STATÂ 330 or ECEÂ 304); any programming language such as C, Python or Java is beneficial but not required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing small- and large-scale data sets
Using different data for various real-world traffic/transportation applications
Basic knowledge in C, Python or Java programming language
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making based on data analysis

courseDescription: Introduction to concepts, principles, challenges, and research in major areas of artificial intelligence. Areas of discussion include: natural language and vision processing, machine learning, machine logic and reasoning, robotics, expert and mundane systems. Laboratory work required.

Part one of the senior capstone design experience for modeling and simulation engineering majors. Lectures focus on providing professional orientation and exploration of the M&S design process.  Written communication, oral communication and information literary skills are stressed.  Individual and group design projects focus on the conduct of a complete M&S project.  Industry-sponsored projects are an option.  Individual and team reports and oral presentations are required.  This is a writing intensive course.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing individual and group design projects

courseDescription: Part two of the senior capstone design experience for modeling and simulation engineering majors.  Lectures focus on providing professional orientation and exploration of the M&S design process.  Written communication, oral communication and information literacy skills are stressed.  Individual and group design projects focus on the conduct of a complete M&S project.  Industry-sponsored projects are an option.  Individual and team reports and oral presentations are required.

courseTitle: Topics in Modeling and Simulation Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in modeling and simulation engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of recent developments in modeling and simulation engineering
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss complex technical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in modeling and simulation scenarios
Analytical thinking for creating and improving models

courseTitle: Topics in Modeling and Simulation Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on the recent developments in modeling and simulation engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Keeping up with recent technological advancements
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing recent developments in the field
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying appropriate modeling techniques for specific situations
Evaluating the effectiveness of different simulation engineering methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing information about the latest methods and tools

courseTitle: Independent Study in Modeling and Simulation Engineering
courseDescription: Individual analytical, computational, and/or experimental study in an area seleted by the student.  Supervised and approved by the advisor.

An introductory course focused on game development theory and modern practices with emphasis on educational game development.  Topics include game architecture, computer graphics theory, user interaction, audio, high level shading language, animation, physics, and artificial intelligence.  The developed games can run on a variety of computer, mobile, and gaming platforms.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking for user interaction design
Problem-solving in audio design for games
Analyzing and solving problems in animation
Analyzing and resolving game physics issues

The techniques and concepts discussed typically include UML, concept graphs, Bayesian nets, Markov models, Petri nets, system dynamics, Bond graphs, etc. Students will report on a particular technique and team to implement a chosen system model. (cross-listed with ECEÂ 510)
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and presenting reports on modeling techniques

Cross-listed with ECEÂ 516.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of information protection and assurance
Proficiency in computer systems and networks security

Knowledge of Internet security protocol and standards

Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and attack modern security systems
Hands-on experience in problem-solving using cryptographic algorithms

Cross-listed with ECEÂ 519.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of basic concepts, technologies and applications of CPS
Knowledge of fundamental CPS security challenges
Implementing practical countermeasures in CPS security
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex CPS concepts and issues
Sharing knowledge and best practices in CPS security
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing CPS infrastructures for potential vulnerabilities
Developing solutions to address CPS security challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to prioritize and manage CPS security issues
Leadership in implementing CPS security measures

It covers digital image and signal processing basics such as sampling and discrete Fourier transform, computer graphics fundamentals, visualization principles, and software architecture for visualization in modeling and simulation. Written communication and information literacy skills are stressed in this course. (Cross listed with ECEÂ 506.) (Offered fall)
Technical and Digital Skills: Software architecture for visualization in modeling and simulation

Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis techniques for modeling and simulation

Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation of ROC and FROC analysis

Course topics include: robotic control, architectures, and sensors as well as more advanced concepts such as error propagation, localization, mapping and autonomy. Fundamental principles of cyber security and their applications for protecting software and information assets of individual computers and large networked systems are explored. Anatomy of some sample attacks designed to compromise confidentiality, integrity and availability of cyber systems are discussed.

Practices of using different data for various real-world traffic/transportation applications and decision making will also be discussed., STATÂ 330 or ECEÂ 304); any programming language such as C, Python or Java is beneficial but not required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Programming in C, Python or Java
Working with small- and large-scale data sets
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying data analytics to real-world transportation applications
Decision making based on data analysis

courseDescription: Introduction to concepts, principles, challenges, and research in major areas of artificial intelligence. Areas of discussion include: natural language and vision processing, machine learning, machine logic and reasoning, robotics, expert and mundane systems. Laboratory work required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of expert and mundane systems

courseTitle: Topics in Modeling and Simulation Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in modeling and simulation engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Adaptation to recent technological advancements in the field
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating complex modeling and simulation concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to new developments in the field

courseTitle: Topics in Modeling and Simulation Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on the recent developments in modeling and simulation engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of modeling and simulation concepts
Keeping up-to-date with recent developments in the field
Use of relevant modeling and simulation software
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex modeling and simulation concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of modeling and simulation methodologies

courseTitle: Independent Study in Modeling and Simulation Engineering
courseDescription: Individual analytical, computational, and/or experimental study in an area selected by the student.  Supervised and approved by the advisor.

Modeling and simulation (M&S) discipline surveyed at an overview level of detail.  Basic terminology, modeling methods, and simulation paradigms are introduced.  Applications of M&S in various disciplines are discussed.  The course provides a general conceptual framework for those interested in using M&S and for further studies in M&S.  Not open to MSVE degree seeking students.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of M&S in various disciplines
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the suitability of M&S for different tasks

courseDescription: An introduction to the modeling and simulation discipline.  Introduction to discrete event simulation (DES) including simulation methodology, input data modeling, output data analysis, and an overview of DES tools.  Introduction to continuous simulation (CS) including simulation methodology, differential equation models, numerical solution techniques, and an overview of CS tools.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of discrete event simulation (DES) methodologies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of input and output data

courseDescription: Course develops the computer software skills necessary for the design and development of simulation software.  Topics covered include software architectures, software engineering, software design, object-oriented programming, abstract data types and classes, data structures, algorithms, and testing and debugging techniques.  Software design and development of simulation systems (discrete-event, continuous, and Monte Carlo) are emphasized.
Technical and Digital Skills: Working with abstract data types and classes
Simulation software development (discrete-event, continuous, and Monte Carlo)

courseDescription: Course provides a practical treatment of design, analysis, implementation and applications of algorithms. Topics include multiple learning models: linear models, neural networks, support vector machines, instance-based learning, Bayesian learning, genetic algorithms, ensemble learning, reinforcement learning, unsupervised learning, etc. (Cross listed with ECEÂ 607)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving using multiple learning models

courseDescription: Students will learn the essential aspects of the system architecture paradigm through environment and analysis of multiple architecture framework and enterprise engineering, such as IDEFO, TOGAF, DODAF and OPM. Emphasis on system modeling and enterprise engineering.  (Cross listed with ENMAÂ 660)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of architecture frameworks like IDEFO, TOGAF, DODAF and OPM
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and solving system design issues

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.  Student participation for credit based on academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluation procedures as formally determined by the program and the Cooperative Education/Career Development Services program prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conveying academic relevance of the work experience
Effective communication with program and Cooperative Education/Career Development Services program
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Determining academic relevance of work experience
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing work experience according to program criteria

courseDescription: Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired. Allows students an opportunity to gain short duration career-related experience.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to new tasks and challenges

courseDescription: Academic requirements will be established by the graduate program director and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students an opportunity to gain short-duration career related experience.  Student is usually employedâthis is an additional project beyond the duties of the studentâs employment.
Technical and Digital Skills: Specialized knowledge related to student's field of study
Adapting academic learning to practical applications
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with graduate program director
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking for executing additional projects beyond regular duties

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of functioning of cyber systems including how a computer interacts with the outside world. The composition of critical infrastructure and functioning of different engineered systems that form critical infrastructure are discussed. Mutual dependence and interactions between cyber systems and other engineered systems and the resulting security risks are also explored. (Cross-listed with ENMAÂ 670.)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of interaction between cyber systems and engineered systems
Assessing security risks in cyber systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing interactions and dependencies in cyber systems

courseDescription: This course discusses how to develop cyber threat models using attack graphs/trees, STRIDE, Universal Modeling Language (UML), attack graphs/trees and common of risk analysis tools. Course also discusses the need for quantitative security analysis and formal validation of security models and basic principles of formal model validation. (Cross-listed with ENMA 673.)
Technical and Digital Skills: Executing formal validation of security models

courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in modeling and simulation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of recent trends in modeling and simulation

courseTitle: Independent Study in Modeling and Simulation
courseDescription: Individual study selected by the student.  Supervised and approved by a faculty member with the approval of the graduate program director.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of modeling and simulation software

courseDescription: Research leading to the Master of Science thesis.

As machine age problems have given way to systems age messes, the underlying complexity associated with understanding these situations has increased exponentially.  Accordingly, the methods we use to address these situations must evolve as well.  This course will introduce students to a method for thinking holistically about problems and messes conceptually founded in systems theory.  This paradigm, known as systemic thinking, will be contrasted with traditional systematic thinking, and practical guidelines for the deployment of a systemic thinking approach will be provided.  This paradigm will increase the student's ability to make rational decisions in complex environments.  (Cross listed with ENMAÂ 702).
Technical and Digital Skills: Differentiating between systemic and systematic thinking
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Guidelines deployment for systemic thinking approach

courseDescription: Covers advanced methods in Operations Research and Optimization. Focus will be on developing models and their applications in different domains including manufacturing and service. Modern optimization tools will be used to implement models for case studies, projects and research papers. The knowledge of programming and spreadsheets is expected. Contact instructor for more details. (Cross-listed with ENMAÂ 703).
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of optimization methods in various domains
Implementation of models for case studies, projects, and research papers
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with instructor for course details
Presentation of case studies, projects, and research papers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of manufacturing and service domains
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of case studies, projects and research papers

courseDescription: The purpose of the course is to provide an understanding of the finite element method (FEM) as derived from an integral formulation perspective.  The course will demonstrate the solutions of (1-D and 2-D) continuum mechanics problems such as solid mechanics, fluid mechanics and heat transfer.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the finite element method (FEM)
Solution derivation for 1-D and 2-D continuum mechanics problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and solving continuum mechanics problems

courseTitle: High Performance Computing Simulation and Data Analytics
courseDescription: Introduction to modern high performance computing platforms including top supercomputers and accelerators. Discussion of parallel architectures, performance, programming models, and software development issues. Case studies of scientific and engineering simulations will be explored. Students will have an opportunity to work on parallelization of problems from their research areas. Project presentations are required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of high performance computing platforms
Software development for high performance computing

courseDescription: This course provides detailed numerical step-by-step procedures to exploit parallel and sparse computation under MPI (Message Passing Interface) computer environments.  Large-scale engineering/science applications are emphasized.  Simultaneous linear equations are discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of MPI (Message Passing Interface) computer environments
Ability to exploit parallel and sparse computation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to follow numerical step-by-step procedures
Ability to apply computation to solve large-scale problems

courseTitle: Principles of Combat Modeling and Simulation
courseDescription: Principles of combat modeling and simulation.  Introduction including history, basic definitions, and best practice.  Algorithms for modeling movement, sensing effects and behavior.  Overview of modern combat models.  Interoperability and integration into operational environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Interoperability and integration into operational environments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and apply combat models
Problem-solving through integration and interoperability issues

courseDescription: The focus of the course is on identification and investigation of mathematical and logical structures that form the foundation for computational simulation.  Topics include: foundations of simulation theory in logic, discrete mathematics, and computability; simulation formalisms, including DEVS; interoperability protocols; and computational complexity.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of simulation theory in logic
Familiarity with simulation formalisms, including DEVS
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and investigation of mathematical and logical structures

courseDescription: Well-designed graphical media capitalizes on human facilities for processing visual information and thereby improves comprehension, memory, inference, and decision making.  This course teaches techniques and algorithms for creating effective visualizations based on principles and techniques from graphic design, visual art, perceptual psychology and cognitive science.  Both users and developers of visualization tools and systems will benefit from this course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementing principles from graphic design, visual art, perceptual psychology and cognitive science into visualizations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with users and developers of visualization tools
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Improving comprehension, memory, inference, and decision making through visualizations
Applying perceptual psychology and cognitive science principles to problem solving
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading the design and implementation of visualizations

courseDescription: The course covers the theory and techniques for building effective and efficient synthetic environments for modeling and simulation applications. Topics include physics, artificial intelligence, virtual reality, and advanced modeling and rendering. The emphasis is on producing visually realistic synthetic environments based on effective approximations of physics and other related principles.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and implementation of AI in synthetic environments

courseTitle: Advanced Analysis for Modeling and Simulation
courseDescription: An introduction to stochastic dependence and Bayesian analysis techniques for conducting modeling and simulation studies. Topics include: measures of dependence, common multivariate distributions, sampling from multivariate distributions, elementary time series models and Bayesian statistics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to sample from multivariate distributions
Understanding of elementary time series models

courseDescription: Modeling Global Events introduces modeling and simulation as a tool for expanding our understanding of events that have shaped the global environment of the 21st century.  Students will review real-world case studies and then analyze these case studies via system dynamics, agent-based, social network, and game theory modeling paradigms. This course is designed to develop empirical research skills, conceptual modeling expertise, and model construction.  Students will understand how to analyze, verify, and validate a model.

This course provides a rigorous introduction to transportation network modeling, with special emphasis on network equilibrium problems. Topics include: elementary graph theory, shortest path problem nonlinear optimization, optimization of univariate functions, deterministic and stochastic user equilibrium. (Cross-listed with CEEÂ 774).
Fundamental models and algorithms in optimization, stochastic modeling and parallel computing will be discussed and illustrated with transportation applications. (Cross-listed with CEEÂ 775)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving using optimization and stochastic models

courseDescription: Principles of simulation modeling, microscopic, mesoscopic, and macroscopic traffic simulation models.  Course explores diver behavior in networks, calibration and validation of traffic simulation models, and use of traffic simulation software. (Cross-listed with CEEÂ 776)
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of microscopic, mesoscopic, and macroscopic traffic simulation models
Calibration and validation of traffic simulation models

courseDescription: Advanced topics in machine learning and pattern recognition systems. Data reduction techniques including principle component analysis, independent component analysis and manifold learning. Introduction to sparse coding and deep learning for data representation and feature extraction. (Cross-listed with ECEÂ 780)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of machine learning and pattern recognition systems
Deep learning for data representation and feature extraction
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to use deep learning for feature extraction

courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in modeling and simulation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge on recent developments in modeling and simulation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to apply modeling and simulation techniques to solve real-world problems
Analytical thinking to understand and interpret simulation results

courseTitle: Independent Study in Modeling and Simulation
courseDescription: Individual study selected by the student.  Supervised and approved by a faculty member with the approval of the graduate program director.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of appropriate software for modeling and simulations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating project progress and findings to supervisor

courseDescription: As machine age problems have given way to systems age messes, the underlying complexity associated with understanding these situations has increased exponentially.  Accordingly, the methods we use to address these situations must evolve as well.  This course will introduce students to a method for thinking holistically about problems and messes conceptually founded in systems theory.  This paradigm, known as systemic thinking, will be contrasted with traditional systematic thinking, and practical guidelines for the deployment of a systemic thinking approach will be provided.  This paradigm will increase the student's ability to make rational decisions in complex environments.  (Cross listed with ENMAÂ 802).

Covers advanced methods in Operations Research and Optimization. Focus will be on developing models and their applications in different domains including manufacturing and service. Modern optimization tools will be used to implement models for case studies, projects and research papers. The knowledge of programming and spreadsheets is expected. Contact instructor for more details. (Cross-listed with ENMAÂ 803).
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration on Projects and Research Papers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of Models in Various Domains
Optimization of Manufacturing and Service Processes

courseDescription: The purpose of the course is to provide an understanding of the finite element method (FEM) as derived from an integral formulation perspective.  The course will demonstrate the solutions of (1-D and 2-D) continuum mechanics problems such as solid mechanics, fluid mechanics and heat transfer.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in solid mechanics, fluid mechanics and heat transfer
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying the integral formulation perspective to solve problems

courseTitle: High Performance Computing Simulation and Data Analytics
courseDescription: Introduction to modern high performance computing platforms including top supercomputers and accelerators. Discussion of parallel architectures, performance, programming models, and software development issues. Case studies of scientific and engineering simulations will be explored. Students will have an opportunity to work on parallelization of problems from their research areas. Project presentations are required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of high performance computing platforms
Knowledge of top supercomputers and accelerators
Application of programming models in high performance computing
Software development for high performance computing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of scientific and engineering simulations

courseDescription: This course provides detailed numerical step-by-step procedures to exploit parallel and sparse computation under MPI (Message Passing Interface) computer environments.  Large-scale engineering/science applications are emphasized.  Simultaneous linear equations are discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Exploiting parallel and sparse computation under MPI environments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying solutions for complex computational problems

courseTitle: Principles of Combat Modeling and Simulation
courseDescription: Principles of combat modeling and simulation.  Introduction including history, basic definitions, and best practice.  Algorithms for modeling movement, sensing effects and behavior.  Overview of modern combat models.  Interoperability and integration into operational environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Skills in modeling movement, sensing effects and behavior
Integration of models into operational environments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in establishing best practices for combat modeling and simulation

courseDescription: The focus of the course is on identification and investigation of mathematical and logical structures that form the foundation for computational simulation.  Topics include: foundations of simulation theory in logic, discrete mathematics, and computability; simulation formalisms, including DEVS; interoperability protocols; and computational complexity.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of simulation theory in logic
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of mathematical and logical structures

courseDescription: Well-designed graphical media capitalizes on human facilities for processing visual information and thereby improves comprehension, memory, inference, and decision making.  This course teaches techniques and algorithms for creating effective visualizations based on principles and techniques from graphic design, visual art, perceptual psychology and cognitive science.  Both users and developers of visualization tools and systems will benefit from this course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of perceptual psychology and cognitive science to visualization
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting complex information through visual media
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Improving comprehension and decision making through visual media
Applying inference techniques to visual data
Understanding of human visual information processing

courseDescription: The course covers the theory and techniques for building effective and efficient synthetic environments for modeling and simulation applications. Topics include physics, artificial intelligence, virtual reality, and advanced modeling and rendering. The emphasis is on producing visually realistic synthetic environments based on effective approximations of physics and other related principles.
Technical and Digital Skills: Rendering techniques for visually realistic environments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effectively explaining complex synthetic environment concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in the development of efficient synthetic environments
Analytical skills for optimizing synthetic environment performance
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team in synthetic environment development

courseTitle: Advanced Analysis for Modeling and Simulation
courseDescription: An introduction to stochastic dependence and Bayesian analysis techniques for conducting modeling and simulation studies. Topics include: measures of dependence, common multivariate distributions, sampling from multivariate distributions, elementary time series models and Bayesian statistics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge on elementary time series models

courseDescription: Course explores hands-on exposure to state-of-the-art algorithms in medical image analysis, which builds on open-source software (Insight Segmentation and Registration Toolkit - ITK), as well as the principles of medical image acquisition in the modalities of clinical interest. Medical imaging modalities - X-rays, CT, and MRI/ITK image pipeline; image enhancement, feature detection; segmentation - basic techniques, feature-based classification and clustering, graph cuts, active contour and surface models; surface and volume meshing; registration - transformations, similarity criteria; shape and appearance models are all explored and discussed in this course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of state-of-the-art algorithms in medical image analysis
Proficiency in open-source software Insight Segmentation and Registration Toolkit - ITK
Knowledge of medical image acquisition in clinical interest modalities
Familiarity with medical imaging modalities - X-rays, CT, and MRI/ITK image pipeline
Image enhancement and feature detection skills
Understanding of segmentation techniques, feature-based classification and clustering, graph cuts, active contour and surface models
Knowledge of registration transformations and similarity criteria
Understanding of shape and appearance models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to apply state-of-the-art algorithms in medical image analysis
Analytical skills to interpret medical images from various modalities
Problem-solving skills in image segmentation, feature detection, and classification
Ability to apply transformations and evaluate similarity criteria in image registration

courseDescription: Modeling Global Events introduces modeling and simulation as a tool for expanding our understanding of events that have shaped the global environment of the 21st century.  Students will review real-world case studies and then analyze these case studies via system dynamics, agent-based, social network, and game theory modeling paradigms. This course is designed to develop empirical research skills, conceptual modeling expertise, and model construction.  Students will understand how to analyze, verify, and validate a model.

This course provides a rigorous introduction to transportation network modeling, with special emphasis on network equilibrium problems. Topics include: elementary graph theory, shortest path problem nonlinear optimization, optimization of univariate functions, deterministic and stochastic user equilibrium. (Cross-listed with CEEÂ 874).
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Deterministic and stochastic user equilibrium analysis

courseDescription: Fundamental models and algorithms in optimization, stochastic modeling and parallel computing will be discussed and illustrated with transportation applications. (Cross-listed with CEEÂ 875)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and applying appropriate algorithmic solutions

courseDescription: Principles of simulation modeling, microscopic, mesoscopic, and macroscopic traffic simulation models.  Course explores driver behavior in networks, calibration and validation of traffic simulation models, and use of traffic simulation software. (Cross-listed with CEEÂ 876)
Technical and Digital Skills: Microscopic, mesoscopic, and macroscopic traffic simulation models
Calibration and validation of traffic simulation models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving for model calibration and validation
Use of analytical tools in traffic simulation software

courseDescription: Advanced topics in machine learning and pattern recognition systems. Data reduction techniques including principle component analysis, independent component analysis and manifold learning. Introduction to sparse coding and deep learning for data representation and feature extraction. (Cross-listed with ECEÂ 880)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of advanced topics in machine learning
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting complex data sets
Problem solving using advanced machine learning techniques
Analytical thinking with respect to machine learning and pattern recognition systems
Applying data reduction techniques to real-world problems

courseDescription: Directed individual study applying advanced level technical knowledge to identify, formulate and solve a complex, novel problem in Modeling and Simulation.
Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in modeling and simulation.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in modeling and simulation

courseTitle: Independent Study in Modeling and Simulation
courseDescription: Individual study selected by the student.  Supervised and approved by a faculty member with the approval of the graduate program director.
Supervised research prior to passing Ph.D. candidacy exam.
Directed research for the doctoral dissertation.

This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and adhering to graduation requirements

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
